August 30, 1992: Fiction
GERALD'S GAME, by Stephen King. (Viking, $23.50.) Twenty-eight hours of
horror suffered by a woman handcuffed to a bedpost.
THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law
student probes the murder of two Supreme Court justices.
WAITING TO EXHALE, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $22.) The friendships and
romances of four black women in Phoenix.
COLONY, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $20.) Life at a Maine summer
retreat.
FATHERLAND, by Robert Harris. (Random House, $21.) A book set in the Third
Reich -- in 1964.
POSSESSING THE SECRET OF JOY, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $19.95.) The struggles of an African woman to come to terms with the
consequences of female circumcision.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$14.95.) A photographer and a lonely farmer's wife in Iowa.
SWEET LIAR, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $22.) On a visit to New York to track
down her grandmother, a Kentucky woman copes with a mystery dating back to
the Roaring Twenties.
NIGHT OF THE HAWK, by Dale Brown. (Fine/ Putnam, $22.95.) American airmen
and marines undertake to rescue a serviceman in Lithuania.
THE VOLCANO LOVER, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A
romantic novel about Lord Nelson, his lover Emma Hamilton, her husband and
Neapolitan society in the 18th century.
DARK FORCE RISING, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $18.50.) A "Star
Wars" novel.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) Verse
and pictures.
WHERE IS JOE MERCHANT? by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$19.95.) A couple on a wild chase through the Caribbean on the trail of a
deceased rock star who has been sighted there.
ALL THAT REMAINS, by Patricia D. Cornwell. (Scribners, $20.) Searching for the
truth behind the strange deaths of five young couples in Virginia.
EYE OF THE STORM, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $22.95.) An Iraqi tries to kill
August 30, 1992
Non-Fiction
THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The
psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women.
TRUMAN, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A biography of the 33d
President.
DIANA: HER TRUE STORY, by Andrew Morton. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A
biography of the Princess of Wales.
THE LAST TSAR, by Edvard Radzinsky. (Doubleday, $25.) The life of Nicholas II
and his family, and their assassination in 1918.
EARTH IN THE BALANCE, by Al Gore. (Houghton Mifflin, $22.95.) The Vice-
Presidential candidate discusses the environment.
MARILYN: THE LAST TAKE, by Peter Harry Brown and Patte B. Barham. (Dutton,
$23.) Did intrigues in Hollywood boardrooms and in the Kennedys' circle lead to
Marilyn Monroe's death?
WOMEN WHO RUN WITH THE WOLVES, by Clarissa Pinkola Estes. (Ballantine,
$20.) A Jungian analyst reinterprets myths and folk tales to enable women to
understand their psyches.
SAM WALTON: MADE IN AMERICA, by Sam Walton with John Huey.
(Doubleday, $22.50.) The autobiography of the man who created Wal-Mart.
LINCOLN AT GETTYSBURG, by Garry Wills. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) The
address delivered on Nov. 19, 1863, and how it has affected American life.
HEAD TO HEAD, by Lester Thurow. (Morrow, $25.) The upcoming economic
battle among Japan, Europe and the United States.
REVOLUTION FROM WITHIN, by Gloria Steinem. (Little, Brown, $22.95.) The
reflections of a feminist on the struggle to achieve self-esteem.
A BRILLIANT MADNESS, by Patty Duke and Gloria Hochman. (Bantam, $22.50.)
The actress talks about living with manic-depressive illness.
WHO WILL TELL THE PEOPLE, by William Greider. (Simon & Schuster, $25.)
How powerful monied interests dominate the Government.
BACKLASH, by Susan Faludi. (Crown, $24.) A journalist contends that the media
and political groups are staging a war against women's rights.
ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, by Blanche Wiesen Cook. (Viking, $27.50.) The first 49
years of a pre-eminent First Lady.
